All the Knox WebShell changes are available here: https://github.com/apache/knox/tree/webshell
@moresandeep Inviting you to review this very important change! It's critical! Please make it first today!! :)

Looks good :) 
![Looks good](https://media.giphy.com/media/mlvseq9yvZhba/giphy.gif)
@moresandeep @smolnar82 @zeroflag
This was a test PR.
@harshiljhaveri - is this the same PR as #597?

> @harshiljhaveri - is this the same PR as #597?

Yes, PR 597 had conditions to handle null cases as well. Started a new PR to address a different JIRA ticket #.
@smolnar82 @zeroflag

One more general ask: instead of using screenshots of text blocks (configuration, logs, etc...) in the description or comments, please use the 'text block' representation of GitHub PRs. The way it's impossible to copy-paste that content if I wanted to use it. For instance, instead of using this screenshot Please do this: ``` gateway.httpclient.connectionTimeout 8m gateway.httpclient.socketTimeout 10m ```
@zeroflag @smolnar82

Code change looks good. Did you manage to trace back the caller of this function in the code? It should originate from an `init()` or something equivalent. We need to make sure this is not called repeatably but only once.
Thanks, @MrtnBalazs for the detailed description above!

> Code change looks good. Did you manage to trace back the caller of this function in the code? It should originate from an `init()` something equivalent. We need to make sure this is not called repeatably but only once.

Maybe invoking the same curl command 2-3 times could prove that, right?

> Maybe invoking the same curl command 2-3 times could prove that, right?

There might be another code path. It would be good to see it in the code level as well.
I tried invoking the same curl command multiple times, and it logged only the first time. I could'n t trace it back to an init() function.

> I tried invoking the same curl command multiple times, and it logged only the first time. I could'n t trace it back to an init() function.

Yes it's non trivial. I think this can be a good exercise to find out how that works.

I managed to trace it back to GatewayDispatchFilter.java `init()` method, which overrides AbstractGatewayFilter-s `init()` method which comes from the javax.servlet.Filter interface. 
The documentation of this interfaces `init()` method says:
> Called by the web container to indicate to a filter that it is being placed into service.
The servlet container calls the init method exactly once after instantiating the filter. The init method must complete successfully before the filter is asked to do any filtering work.
@zeroflag @smolnar82

Would be better to update the title indicating this is just adding configs to support this feature i.e. "Add configurations for concurrent session verifier feature" - feel free to change the wordings.
This relates to https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-32532

@nanhuirong  - can you please add a unit test to insure that the default value remains false and we don't introduce something that enables it by default? Security minded folks will always want this to be an explicit action to open up.

Thanks for the new patchset, @nanhuirong !
I've just checked [Jetty's API](https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/ssl/SslContextFactory.html#isRenegotiationAllowed()) as well as the [source code](https://git.eclipse.org/c/jetty/org.eclipse.jetty.project.git/tree/jetty-util/src/main/java/org/eclipse/jetty/util/ssl/SslContextFactory.java?h=master#n225) and found that the default value is `true`:
```
[@ManagedAttribute](https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)("Whether renegotiation is allowed") public boolean isRenegotiationAllowed()
Returns:
whether TLS renegotiation is allowed (true by default)
```
Hence the question: why do we want to change the default to `false`?

Cc. @lmccay

> https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)("Whether renegotiation is allowed"

In our scenario，we should provide better security for the gateway. After all, the IP maybe a public IP.

> > [https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)("Whether](https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)(%22Whether) renegotiation is allowed"
> 
> In our scenario，we should provide better security for the gateway. After all, the IP maybe a public IP.

What prevents you to set this new config to `false` in your environment and leave the default as `true` as intended by Jetty developers? They also introduced a limit (defaults to 5) that would fix the original CVE of causing a denial of service (CPU consumption) by performing many renegotiations within a single connection.

> > > [https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)("Whether](https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/jetty-9/org/eclipse/jetty/util/annotation/ManagedAttribute.html)(%22Whether) renegotiation is allowed"
> > 
> > 
> > In our scenario，we should provide better security for the gateway. After all, the IP maybe a public IP.
> 
> What prevents you to set this new config to `false` in your environment and leave the default as `true` as intended by Jetty developers? They also introduced a limit (defaults to 5) that would fix the original CVE of causing a denial of service (CPU consumption) by performing many renegotiations within a single connection.

I got it. I don't notice the limit and update the patchset.

Disabling renegotiation is the more secure mode and I would expect that to actually be the default. Renegotiation had an attack vector a while ago whereby a middle man could renegotiate to a lower - like NONE - algorithm. While this may have been fixed, I don't know of any specific functionality that is blocked by this that requires it to be enabled by default. If this was recently changed to enabled by default in jetty then we should preserve backward compatibility and leave it false. If it was enabled by default previously then making it true by default preserves previous behavior.

> Disabling renegotiation is the more secure mode and I would expect that to actually be the default. Renegotiation had an attack vector a while ago whereby a middle man could renegotiate to a lower - like NONE - algorithm. While this may have been fixed, I don't know of any specific functionality that is blocked by this that requires it to be enabled by default. If this was recently changed to enabled by default in jetty then we should preserve backward compatibility and leave it false. If it was enabled by default previously then making it true by default preserves previous behavior.

The build for arm reports "no sapce". Do you have any idea for it?

> Disabling renegotiation is the more secure mode and I would expect that to actually be the default. Renegotiation had an attack vector a while ago whereby a middle man could renegotiate to a lower - like NONE - algorithm. While this may have been fixed, I don't know of any specific functionality that is blocked by this that requires it to be enabled by default. If this was recently changed to enabled by default in jetty then we should preserve backward compatibility and leave it false. If it was enabled by default previously then making it true by default preserves previous behavior.

The default value is ture for jetty now.
@smolnar82 @lmccay , Can you merge the PR? This is the first PR for me.

> @nanhuirong - we need to get unit tests to insure that previous behavior with only one in the list and new behavior with multiples work as expected and do not regress in the future.

@lmccay -  We need two network cards for this config and can't assume another ip. Thus, I just test the gateway.host properties.
@smolnar82 , Please review the code.
@zeroflag
The plan is to implement the enabling/disabling in the next pull request.

@nanhuirong - thank you for your pull request. I've merged this into master and it will be included in the next release.
Let's also file a JIRA for documentation for this improvement.

> Let's also file a JIRA for documentation for this improvement.

I don't know how to do for this. Do you have any suggestion?

@nanhuirong - sure - start by filing a JIRA and describe what documentation needs to be updated and then you can provide the documentation in the JIRA or follow the process description in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KNOX/Contribution+Process#ContributionProcess-DocumentationContributorWorkflow

Note that the site docs are in subversion, not in github.
So, you will likely have to attach the patch file to the JIRA.

Thanks for your interest and followup!
The follow-up JIRA is created here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KNOX-2790
Is there a JIRA for this?

> Is there a JIRA for this?

I thought i had created one, looks like I did not. 
Edit: created a new JIRA [KNOX-2791](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KNOX-2791)

@smolnar82 Travis CI is failed, and I can't load the detail of failed job. Can you help me to fix this?
@Flamingo93 - Travis CI failed for the ARM64 architecture and it's a known issue by the Knox team. For now, we can disregard that failure.

These changes are handled separately in

- #627

> 

Thanks @lmccay ! For license I added Pty4j to the existing EPLv1 license text, is that fine or should I be copying the entire license text? There is no language in the license that indicates I need a separate copy as long as we clearly indicate that Pty4j uses EPLv1 license (followed by the license text)

> This introduces breaking change, changing to `strict` from `none`. it would be difficult to figure out what went wrong given the errors are thrown on the UI so debugging this would be challenging. Perhaps changing it to `Lax` would be a compromise?

This will actually only break deployments that are relying on an insecure setting. Making this Strict by default is the same as the change that added Secure=true many years ago. In modern deployments, the SSO cookie is only being presented to Knox itself and to therefore to the same domain. This should not break deployments that are configured properly to do this. Now, we could consider this a 2.0 release change and change the default for a new 1.6.x release. 2.0 is a major release and can carry incompatible changes.
Superseded by #648.
Hi @moresandeep Could you please take a look? :）
Hi @risdenk @lmccay @moresandeep @pzampino @smolnar82 Could you please take a look? :)
@smolnar82 @zeroflag
The ARM64 build error is a known issue with Knox/Travis CI integration and can be ignored for now.

Thanks, @debiswal for addressing my direct review comments. There is one more I mentioned above:

> Before we merge your changes, I'd like to ask you to write separate unit test classes for the newly introduced service model generators (there are plenty of samples under the src/test/java folder in the gateway-discovery-cm module.

Without the new test classes, we cannot merge your changes.

> Thanks, @debiswal for addressing my direct review comments. There is one more I mentioned above:
> 
> > Before we merge your changes, I'd like to ask you to write separate unit test classes for the newly introduced service model generators (there are plenty of samples under the src/test/java folder in the gateway-discovery-cm module.
> 
> Without the new test classes, we cannot merge your changes.

@smolnar82 -  Noticed your comments have started looking into it already :)
Superseded by #679.

Thanks, @debiswal for the unit test classes. I also see you changed the following too:

- SSL_ENABLED is registered on the role level (before it was on the service level) in the returning `model` instance
- HTTP and HTTPS ports are registered with their role types instead of their role names in the returning `model` instance

Above, you claimed this was tested before you submitted this PR. So either it wasn't working that time or it's not working now. Could you please confirm that this very recent change is tested properly?

Cc. @zeroflag

Hi @smolnar82 Thank you for review  would like to inform   

Comment 1 :: SSL_ENABLED is registered on the role level (before it was on the service level) in the returning model instance:

            SSL_ENABLED is defined at the role level in CM, so it should be defined on the role level in the model generator as well & earlier it was set in ServiceProperty which is not correct & now it is set to  RoleProperty  .we have changed where we get the property but we have not changed it where we store the property. 
The current patch is tested as well in knox test cluster. 

comment 2 :: HTTP and HTTPS ports are registered with their role types instead of their role names in the returning model instance :

           we noticed  that the existing test expect the role type there for some reason, and other tests also use the role type, so we decided to go and use the role type . Also please note that as we don't know what this property map is doing, and for that we followed other tests and implementations .
@debiswal - please fix the build failure and submit a new PS. Thanks!
Superseded by #682.
@smolnar82 @zeroflag
Excellent work @MrtnBalazs ! I'll take a look soon. Thanks, again, for your hard work and contribution to Apache Knox!
@zeroflag - Could you please explain why those ignore declarations help here? Thanks!

> @zeroflag - Could you please explain why those ignore declarations help here? Thanks!

My understanding is that some of those classes are included in the jdk's rt.jar  as well as some third party dependency an powermock loads them from one location while knox loads them from a different location, causing clashes. But it's difficult to unfold all the details. There is lot's of magic going on inside powermock.
I'm rerunning one more time to see how stable it is.
